CHAPTER IV.

From virtue and vice in general we pass to special virtues and vices. We find that the teaching ol ancient philosophers relates to Avarice, Pride, Lust, Gluttony, Anger, Envy, and Sloth-in other words, to the seven mortal sins. Ol these, all hutone, Anger, relate to pleasure and prosperity; Anger only has to do with adverse circumstances. Let us begin with the former class. Disregard ol wealth was preached and practised by Aristotle and a long series ol philosophers. Seneca and Ptolemy have pointed out that this earth is but an infinitesimal part ol the universe, and that the disputes of contending nations forits possession are like the quarrels oi ants lor an anthill.
